awd_titl_txt: OPUS: CRS -- A Cross-Scale Synthesis in a Disturbance-Mediated System: Integrating Population, Community, and Metacommunity Perspectives
awd_abstract_narration:
We live in a time of rapid environmental change, challenging the ability of species to persist and of ecosystems to thrive. Thus, it is important to understand how living things respond to environmental disturbances. This project will use a long-term data set to determine how hurricanes and droughts in Puerto Rico have affected the lives of snails and slugs.  These creatures may seem trivial but are not -- they play an important role in forests by breaking down dead plants and recycling nutrients. Yet, they are increasingly threatened by unusually strong hurricanes and harsh droughts. The main goal of this project is to predict how populations and groups of species change over time. How resistant or vulnerable are snails and slugs to environmental change, and why?  What can we learn from them? In addition to new analyses of long-term data, the researcher will synthesize results of his past work, focusing on changes that take place at different scales and thatare somehow linked across those scales. The project will also help break down disciplinary barriers by offering courses that bring together teams of students and faculty from basic and applied environmental sciences, statistics and geography to learn together about tough environmental challenges.

Synthetic research will produce theoretical and empirical discoveries that integrate perspectives on disturbance and succession, cross-scale interactions, and metacommunities. A monograph will focus on conceptual refinement and integration of theory on disturbance and succession with that on metacommunities. A second monograph will focus on long-term spatiotemporal patterns at the levels of populations, communities, and metacommunities. Population-level attributes include incidence (presence-absence) and abundance, whereas community-level attributes comprise species richness, evenness, dominance, diversity, and rarity. Each metric will be decomposed into spatial components based on multiplicative and additive models to understand how the hierarchical spatial structure responds to disturbances and subsequently changes during secondary succession. Metacommunity analyses will integrate process-based (i.e., patch dynamics, species sorting, mass effects, and neutrality) and pattern-based (i.e., coherence, range turnover, and range boundary clumping) approaches for understanding the ways in which metacommunities change over time in a hurricane-prone system. A hierarchical approach to variance decomposition will be used to quantify unique variation explained by environmental characteristics, spatial variation of unknown origin, and spatially structured environmental variation. Several emerging statistical approaches for understanding spatiotemporal variation will be explored, including (1) intervention analysis or segmented regression; (2) extended generalized linear mixed model frameworks; and (3) multivariate time series approaches and simultaneous inference procedures that accommodate Poisson or negative binomial error terms for rare or uncommon species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global change is likely to produce a world characterized by warmer temperatures as well as by an increased frequency of extreme events such as hurricanes and droughts. Understanding the consequences of these disturbances on populations (local groups of interacting members of the same species), communities (local groups of interacting species), and metacommunities (suites of interacting communities along gradients that are connected by the dispersal of individuals) can inform natural resource conservation and management decisions as well as help to protect biodiversity that ensures delivery of critical ecosystem services. This project fulfilled two interconnect goals: (1) to leverage the research of the PI over a long career (spanning > 35 years), as well as the data gathered by the PI and colleagues, to quantify long-term ecological dynamics in response to climate-induced disturbances and land use change in the Luquillo Mountains of Puerto Rico, and (2) to contribute to a synthesis of knowledge that broadens our understanding of spatial and temporal dynamics of ecological systems.

In close collaboration with a post-doctoral associate, and other colleagues (25 individuals from the US and abroad), peer-reviewed scientific articles were published (10) or submitted (4) for publication with foci on various themes related to the project. Additional scientific articles were published (3) or submitted for publication (1) by the Principal Investigator and Post-Doctoral Associate, as part of the latter’s professional development plan. To enhance the generality of our understanding, we have explored these themes for plants, insects, and birds, as well as for gastropods (the main study organisms for which we have collected extensive data). In general, we were able to show that the effects of warming on the spatiotemporal dynamics of populations, communities, and metacommunities were overshadowed by the effects of hurricanes, the legacies of previous land use (> 70 years ago), and ecological succession (i.e., changes in the abundances of species because of alterations in their abiotic [non-living] and biotic [living] environment that were initiated by a disturbance event). Moreover, the species of the Luquillo Mountains have been exposed to recurrent hurricanes for many millennia, leading to the evolution of adaptations that enhance the resistance (ability to be unaffected by a disturbance) and resilience (ability to quickly return to pre-disturbance states) of species and ecosystems in the Luquillo Mountains. Nonetheless, we hypothesize that if the magnitude or frequency of disturbances increases in the future, or creates new combinations of environmental characteristics that are outside of the current environmental conditions characteristic of the Luquillo Mountains, then some species may become extirpated, new or invasive species may colonize, and the composition and biodiversity of communities and metacommunities may come to represent novel combinations of taxa with unknown consequences to ecosystem functioning.

Individuals are the focal units that affect spatiotemporal dynamics of populations, communities, or metacommunities. Individuals effectively mediate how those entities respond to disturbance and change during succession. We developed a conceptual model (see attached document, "Willig_Conceptual Model_17 VI 2024") from a fitness perspective that explicitly accounts for tradeoffs among strategic “decisions” about dispersal, survivorship, or reproduction that individuals must confront throughout their lifetimes. As a consequence, we are promoting a revision of the fundamental principles of ecology in which we add a “Dispersal Principle.” More formally, “the dispersal of individuals including their propagules (e.g., spores, seeds, pollen) can act as an agent that enhances homogenization or diversification of populations, communities, or metacommunities, depending on species by site interactions within the context of larger landscapes”. Ultimately, the responses of individual organisms to environmental resources or conditions, including intraspecific and interspecific interactions, leads to differential survivorship, reproduction, or dispersal, with ramifications to the spatiotemporal variation in populations, communities, and metacommunities. Essentially, environmental variability at various levels of the biological hierarchy, would be much different if organisms did not disperse (hence the fundamental nature of our proposition).

This project also informed the design of a transdisciplinary graduate course that engages students in collaborative learning. The course would (1) bring together students from the ecological sciences and quantitative sciences (statistics and mathematics), (2) communicate the conceptual bases for understanding spatiotemporal dynamics at multiple spatial and temporal scales, (3) introduce a variety of quantitative and statistical methods for characterizing those dynamics, and (4) provide training in the informed use of software packages and the interpretation of associated statistical output. Course deliverables include the development of manuscripts for publication in ecological or statistical journals, as well as the development of scientific talks on related themes.
